subject: Re: [junit] Re: Help plz...
msgSnippet: ... It s time for a test. Someone who uses Java needs to do it -- that wouldn t be me. I could do it in Ruby, C#, or Smalltalk, none of which are very germane
messageBody:
On Wednesday, September 24, 2003, at 3:11:08 AM, Chris Dollin wrote:

> On Tuesday 23 September 2003 22:13, Jim Dixon wrote:

>> Look at the bytecode. Whenever you call
>> com.funnyfarm.toplevel.deeper.deeperstill.getondown.WeAreFinallyThere,
>> it's in the bytecode, each and every character.

> The bytecode has a reference into the constant pool, that's true; that has
> a space consequence (the name has to be somewhere) and a time
> consequence (the name has to be looked up at least once, and longer
> names will take longer to be looked up).

It's time for a test. Someone who uses Java needs to do it -- that wouldn't
be me. I could do it in Ruby, C#, or Smalltalk, none of which are very
germane to this group. Something like this:

Write a loop that times itself, using really short names. Duplicate it
with really long names. Time the loops. Repeat until you're sure you've
got data. I'd have them in the same program. It might be desirable to try
it with one of the loops first in the source, then the other, just in
case of garbage collection issues or things like that. Or it might not.

I know what I expect to happen, but I don't know what /will/ happen.

Ron Jeffries
www.XProgramming.com
One test is worth a thousand expert opinions.
-- Bill Nye (The Science Guy)
